initial_story: What the he'll is going on that we are struggling with these facilities that take care of the mentally challenged or health care for Alzheimer's patients that have other medical issues?  St. Mary's in Grand Junction just discharged a friend who broke a hip and has Alzheimer's without rehab for the hip and no place with beds open for Alzheimer's!  Ludicrous!  The "authorities" closed the facility to accommodate "challenged " residents here last year and re-located them to Denver.  Again, ridiculous!  Our health care system is without compassion and based on the bottom line!  The worst part is drug addicts, emergency room mangers of all sorts can get care but we treat those who have health issues as seniors like shit! Sad state of affairs!  Shame on healthcare and those who do not fight for dignity in end of life care!  Shameful!  Politicians should be shamed for not supporting a bill that cares for these people!
stories:
Health care is a hot topic these days. With the Affordable Care Act, more people have access to health insurance than ever before. But is health care really affordable? And what about the quality of care?
Health care costs are rising faster than ever before. In fact, health care costs are expected to rise by more than 7% this year alone. That's a lot of money! And it's not just the cost of health insurance that's going up. The cost of prescription drugs is also increasing. In fact, the cost of prescription drugs is expected to increase by more than 10% this year.
So what can we do to keep health care costs down? One way is to make sure we're getting the best quality care possible. Unfortunately, that's not always easy. In fact, sometimes it seems like the best quality care is the most expensive.
That's why it's important to do your research before you choose a health care provider. Make sure you understand what services are included in your insurance policy. And be sure to ask about the cost of any additional services you may need.
Another way to keep health care costs down is to take advantage of preventive care. That means getting regular check-ups and screenings. It also means taking steps to prevent illness and injury.
For example, if you're a smoker, quitting smoking is one of the best things you can do for your health. It's also one of the best things you can do for your wallet. That's because smoking is a major cause of health problems, and it's also a major expense.
The bottom line is that health care is a complex and ever-changing field. And it's important to stay informed so you can make the best decisions for your health and your wallet.

The cost of life is rising, and so is the cost of living. That's why it's important to stay informed about the costs of things, and to find ways to keep the cost of living down.

One way to keep the cost of living down is to buy in bulk. This means buying things in large quantities, which will lower the cost per unit. For example, if you buy a year's worth of groceries at a time, you'll pay less per item than if you buy groceries once a week.

Another way to keep the cost of living down is to take advantage of discounts. For example, many stores offer discounts on certain items if you buy them in bulk. You can also find discounts on things like clothes and furniture by searching online.

Finally, you can save money by living a simpler lifestyle. This means reducing the number of things you own, and living in a smaller space. You can also save money by cooking your own meals, and by avoiding expensive activities.

So, what can you do to keep the cost of living down? Here are a few ideas:

1. Buy in bulk.

2. Take advantage of discounts.

3. Live a simpler lifestyle.

4. Cook your own meals.

5. Avoid expensive activities.

In this digital age, it's becoming increasingly difficult to avoid being connected. Whether it's through social media, email, or the internet in general, we are constantly being bombarded with information. For some, this is a welcome distraction from the everyday hustle and bustle of life. For others, it can be a bit overwhelming.

If you're someone who falls into the latter category, you may want to consider unplugging for a day or two. This doesn't mean you have to completely disconnect from the world - you can still use your phone for calls and texts. But you should try to avoid using your computer or any other digital devices.

Instead, take some time to relax and recharge. Go for a walk, read a book, or just sit and enjoy the silence. You may be surprised at how much better you feel afterwards.

You wake up and check your phone, as you do every morning. There's a text from your boss, asking you to come in for a meeting. You groan. You were hoping for a day off.

You reply to the text, asking if you can reschedule. Your boss replies: "I'm sorry, but this meeting is very important. Can you be here in an hour?"

You sigh and get ready for work. On the way, you stop by the coffee shop and grab a cup of coffee. You need all the caffeine you can get.

You arrive at work and head to the meeting room. Your boss is already there, along with the other members of the team.

"Sorry I'm late," you say.

"That's okay," your boss says. "We were just about to start."

The meeting begins. Your boss goes over the agenda. There are a lot of items to discuss.

You listen intently, taking notes. This is important stuff.

After the meeting, you head back to your desk. You've got a lot of work to do.

But first, you need to take a break. You head to the coffee shop and get another cup of coffee. You need all the caffeine you can get.

You sit down at your desk and get to work. You're making good progress when you suddenly get a text. It's your boss.

"Can you come to my office?"

You reply: "Sure, I'll be right there."

You head to your boss's office and knock on the door.

"Come in," your boss says.

You enter the office and sit down.

"So, what did you think of the meeting?" your boss asks.

"I thought it was great," you say. "We covered a lot of ground."

"That's good to hear," your boss says. "I was worried that you might not be paying attention."

"I was paying attention," you say. "I took notes."

"That's good," your boss says. "I'm glad you were paying attention."

Your boss goes on to discuss the items from the meeting that need to be addressed. You listen intently, taking notes. This is important stuff.

You reply to the text, asking if you can reschedule. Your boss replies: "I'm sorry, but this meeting is very important. Can you be here in an hour?"

You sigh and get ready for work. On the way, you stop by the coffee shop and grab a cup of coffee. You need all the caffeine you can get.

You arrive at work and head to the meeting room. Your boss is already there, along with the other members of the team.

"Sorry I'm late," you say.

"That's okay," your boss says. "We were just about to start."

The meeting begins. Your boss goes over the agenda. There are a lot of items to discuss.

You listen intently, taking notes. This is important stuff.

After the meeting, you head back to your desk. You've got a lot of work to do.

But first, you need to take a break. You head to the coffee shop and get another cup of coffee. You need all the caffeine you can get.

You sit down at your desk and get to work. You're making good progress when you suddenly get a text. It's your boss.

"Can you come to my office?"

You reply: "Sure, I'll be right there."

You head to your boss's office and knock on the door.

"Come in," your boss says.

You enter the office and sit down.

"So, what did you think of the meeting?" your boss asks.

"I thought it was great," you say. "We covered a lot of ground."

"That's good to hear," your boss says. "I was worried that you might not be paying attention."

"I was paying attention," you say. "I took notes."

"That's good," your boss says. "I'm glad you were paying attention."
